title: Successes, Failures and Learning From Them

author: Haym Hirsh, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

segmentation: So I'm I'm her Shema faculty members University.

I'm currently kind of on loan at the National Science Foundation, where I'm now directing the Division of Information Intelligence Systems, and it's actually giving me a whole new perspective on issues that are not just about research issues and you'll see that come out in my presentation.
Also, I want to thank the organizers of the conference in the panel for saying we have a panel to focus not just on successes, but also on failures.
Anyone who's?
Sat at a table with me at lunch or dinner the last couple of days have been subjected to my wanting to talk about what our failures are.
Data mining I think.
I certainly got a lot out of it and I hope other people have two and I encourage you all to generally not just contemplate on your own but also with others.
What are the things that we're not doing right with the things we can do better?
And so I'll reflect a little that here in my presentation.
But and thank all of you who've been sitting at meals with me during the conference, and none of this necessarily reflect your thoughts, but certainly has influenced mind.

So pretty obvious in my presentation here, I'm going to be constrained data mining pretty broadly about data and trying to extract information from it, and I guess I don't need to apologize for that because pretty much everyone for me has done so as well.

Actually, I'm going to focus more on failure.
There's an of a particular sort, but let me just hit on some of my favorite datamining successes and I can do it pretty quickly because most of them seem to be successes that other people like.
Web search, whether we're doing analysis of term, frequencies, or webpage linkages, we're analyzing massive amounts of data to great success.
Spam filtering.
Using probabilistic methods, Bayesian methods using machine learning recommender systems.

Recently I've been trying to buy a camcorder and as soon as I go to something like Consumer Reports and get the name of one I I go to Amazon and look it up just to see what Amazon recommends back to me as other things that I should be looking about.
So recommender systems have definitely affected the way I do shopping and such.
Cited machine translation.

Google's example of first time participating in the NIST language translation task in Chinese and Arabic outperformed everyone else, even though at least the Chinese competition and maybe also the Arabic.
No one on the team, actually spoke the language.
It's all based on massive amounts of data.
And then finally, people talked about scaling, and in particular we're seeing a particular kind of scaling where companies like Google, Yahoo, etc.
Have have come to a better understanding of how we can take massive data analysis tasks and formulate them in ways that we can execute them efficiently quickly.
The kinds of things that you need for quick responses from Google, etc.
And so we now understand the scalability algorithms in a particular way that I think is a great success.
We're not doing data mining using distributed parallel processing the way everyone else does.
There's a distinct.
Area here Randy Bryant at CMU has an article called Data Intensive Supercomputing that lays out why this is something distinctive I think particularly well, so those are.

Of technical things and one of the interesting things I think about these technical examples is a lot of the success is coming not from sophisticated algorithms, but just from the sheer amount of data.
And as we've gained more and more data, our successes are coming from the access to data, not from necessarily being smart.
That's not to say that smart algorithms won't help us, but.
Looking at the ones that I pulled out, I realized that the successes came from measurements, data, sociological successes, then everyones pointed out.

the United States used to be primarily focused in the counties and now we're needing to generate voter registration rolls at a state level, and in the case of Florida, so voters are not allowed.
People are not allowed to vote if you're a convicted felon.

What was the?

Had called Terrorism Information awareness and as it's described here, it was developing software that could examine the computerized travel, credit, medical and other records of Americans and others around the world to search for telltale activities that might reveal preparations for terrorist attack and turn out that got tremendous amount of political attention.

None of these are my actually putting up a political position on any of these issues.

Unity of effort and sharing information.

Bad data mining.

Technology actually makes it possible to do and also us as researchers, regardless of whether we're working in data mining or anything in technology, the effects of our technology have ramifications.

Social, ethical, moral, and we all need to think about not just what the research we're doing is, but what are the ways it could be used, and whether that's good or bad and not to say that we're necessarily doing things that are going to be bad, but we at least need to think about these things as we're doing our work, so that's a pretty long winded way of saying that one of our failures is we're not.
Being perceived accurately and we have to be sensitive to that.
And find the last point that I want to raise is one of the things that we do is technologists is.

We invent the landscape in which people talk about trade offs such as civil liberties versus Homeland Security, and part of the challenge for us is to invent new technologies that we didn't have cryptography, certain ways of communicating that we want to keep information private wasn't possible once we were able to come up with cryptographic schemes, we now can communicate privately open.
That's both good and bad debt, privacy preserving data mining.
It's something that's active.
We don't necessarily have solutions to the problem, but.
The way the.

The trade offs are being articulated or as a function of the technology as it is today, and that technology is constantly evolving as we get more and more good ideas in privacy, preserving data, mining the whole basis for the discussion about our tradeoffs may change.
OK, so how we doing on time?
Alright, so.
Let me just quickly then add end with two final points.
Other failures I mentioned about the value of benchmarks allowing us to compare one another and move forward in a more scholarly scientific way.
But the problem is that these benchmarks.

These datasets are a reflection of the kinds of problems that we think we're going to be playing our algorithms to, and when they were generated in 1989 or 1986 or 1993, their reflection of the kinds of problems that we thought our computational capabilities or algorithms were able to handle, but the datasets need to constantly evolve.
They represent the ambitions for our field.

And as we develop new algorithms, simply saying it works on the UC Irvine repository and a bunch of data sets that were generated 10 years ago doesn't necessarily give us insight into what our algorithms to be able to do today.
What are the important problems today?
And so, in some sense, datasets are giving us Blinders that don't let us actually target the key crucial issues for our field.
So it's both good and bad.
And it related issue to this is many of us are excited about the idea of doing data mining and research in the context of.
Grounded applications, well, just because you've got a data set from UC Irvine that's in molecular biology doesn't mean you're doing applications.
It's really important that there's someone there who actually knows about the domain.
Who cares about the results?
So ask yourself, are you?
If you're really doing something that's relevant to applications you know who is the person you know that's actually going to care about the results of your work.
And then finally reproducible results.

This is something that just I've been confronting, especially now at NSF we find someone who has research using a data set that they got from some company that they've signed away their lives that there never gonna let anyone else use and we get a paper because it really is some interesting insights for but no one else is going to be able to replicate those same experiments because they don't have access to the data.
Is that bad?
I don't know.
I think it's something that we as a field need to think about science about reproducibility, but the fundamental nature of our field is reusing datasets that.

Have commercial value or other restricted value for regulatory reasons or what have you and so how do we do data mining in a way that allows us to be more scholarly in our in our work I have more slides, but I don't have time.
So thank you all.
